page.title: 01Claverley and Farmcote
page.content: The Village of Claerley is dominated by the Norman and medieval Church, built from local red sandstone. Time has not changed the centre of the village greatly, which still retains many charming old timber framed, black and white buildings. From the bull Ring, climbing the left side of Hight street, are the three village pubs, fondly referred to by the locals as the bottom, the middle and the top. Nearby, a few housing developments have been built. One by the Council in 1955 and several by commercial builders during the 1960's and since. Most occupants of the latter commute daily to surrounding towns. The area to the south and west contains Beobridge, Farmcote, Upper Farmcote, Sandford, Woundale and Chyknell, all local employment.
